The Solar System is the Sun and everything that revolves in orbit around it. This includes the eight planets and their moons, asteroids and numerous comets. All are held in orbit around the Sun by the strong gravity force from the sun.
In the solar system there are 8 planets; our planet is Earth, next to it there are seven more planets:

Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System (excluding Pluto), and is as well the closest to the Sun. The surface of this planet is much like the "seas" of our Moon, being also very abundant in craters. It has begun to be studied in detail since the beginning of the century. Mercury can be seen with the naked eye, but sometimes you may need binoculars to observe it.

The second planet, Venus, is well known for glowing at dawn or dusk, a feature that has earned it the nickname "bright star". It\'s a beautiful planet to observe with the naked eye. If you have a telescope and you get to locate it, you will find that Venus can get to show phases like the Moon. This curious phenomenon is because the planet is closer to the Sun than the Earth; so the sunlight illuminates it from different angles. The temperature of Venus is higher than Mercury, even though it is farther from the sun. An astronomer named Carl Sagan discovered the cause of this mystery, and so we got to know that this is due to the presence of gases in the atmosphere, causing Venus a large greenhouse effect, retaining the heat it receives from the sun.

The earth is a big ball of rock, slightly flattened at the poles, that goes around the Sun in 365 days and almost 6 hours. More than 70% of the earth\'s surface is covered by oceans of liquid water. The Earth is inhabited by millions and millions of living beings and is the site from which we are beginning to know the universe as it is. Only astronauts have managed to see Earth from space, some from orbit, hundreds of kilometers away, and others from the moon, hundreds of thousands of kilometers away.

Mars is farther from the sun than Earth, which makes it cooler. Mars has huge volcanoes, one of them, Mount Olympus, is the largest in the entire solar system. It is frozen on its surface and contains underground water, as demonstrated by the Phoenix robot. In the future we might find life on this planet. Mars is clearly visible to the naked eye.

Jupiter is as huge as 1,321 Earths. Although the Sun is much larger, of course, as 984 times bigger than Jupiter. It is a gas planet (The Gas Giant) and is capable of emitting radio waves. Jupiter\'s atmosphere is of enormous complexity, and its study may help us understand better how atmospheric phenomena on Earth and the famous climate change occur. In the atmosphere of Jupiter, storms and anticyclones larger than the whole planet Earth take place, with winds reaching speeds of unimaginable magnitude. It is accompanied by more than 60 satellites, the most known Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto, being the four visible with some binoculars from the Earth. Jupiter is perfectly visible to the naked eye.

Saturn always catches everyone\'s attention because of that imposing ring around it. In fact it is not a single ring, they are several. These rings are composed of millions of pieces of ice, some as big as a building, and others tiny, like a speck of dust. If you are able to find Saturn in the sky (it is observable to the naked eye) and then you equip yourself with a telescope, you will see one of the greatest wonders of nature: the rings of Saturn. Saturn is not the only planet with rings, but it is the one with the most beautiful ones. All gas planets have rings, although it is very difficult to see them. \nAnd one last curiosity: composed mainly of gas and being as large compared to its mass, Saturn would float in the sea, assuming it could fit , of course.

Uranus is the first planet discovered with a telescope, by musician and astronomer William Herschel in 1781, although it is true that you can see it with the naked eye and certain African tribes had observed it long before him. \nAll the planets revolve around an axis, and all axes of all the planets are slightly inclined, but the planet with the axis of rotation most tilted is Uranus, with almost 98 °.

Neptune glows with a beautiful deep blue color and was the first planet discovered with mathematics. It was precisely Le Verrier the one who indicated through his mathematical calculations, what would its position be in the sky, so that astronomer Galle discovered the planet in 1846 with a telescope. In all gas planets there are winds of unusual strength, and in Neptune, like Jupiter, storms the size of whole planets are formed. Scientists believe that Neptune could have changed its position countless times with Uranus million years ago, so it may not have always been the farthest planet from the Sun.
The largest satellites in the solar system
The 6 largest satellites in the solar system

It is one of the Jovian moons or Galileans from Jupiter and is the largest in the solar system. Its name comes from a beautiful Trojan prince, son of the eponymous Tros (or Laomedonte); Ganymede became the lover of Zeus and the cupbearer of the gods. On the etymology of its name; Robert Graves (The Greek Myths) proposes: ganuesthai + medea, "rejoicing in virility". This name was popularized from the mid-twentieth century.

It is the largest satellite of Saturn and is easily visible with amateur telescopes. The name "Titan" and the other seven Saturn satellites known by John Herschel (son of William Herschel) comes from its publication in 1847 of his observations on Saturn he suggested the names of the Titans, sisters and brothers of Cronos ( the Greek name for the Roman god of time Saturn) as a more effective method for naming the satellites of Saturn hitherto designated by Roman numerals in the order of proximity to the planet.

The satellite is named after one of the many lovers of Zeus, according to Greek mythology, where Callisto was a nymph (or, according to other sources, daughter of Lycaon) who was associated with the goddess of hunting Artemis. The name was proposed by astronomer Simon Marius soon after the discovery of the satellite. Marius attributed the suggestion to Johannes Kepler. However, the names of the Galilean satellites fell into disuse for a considerable time and not again extended their use until the mid-twentieth century. In much of the relatively recent astronomical literature, Callisto is quoted by Roman numeral designation, Jupiter IV, a system introduced by Galileo, or as the "fourth satellite of Jupiter"
It is the third Jovian or Galilean moon of Jupiter. Named Io, one of the many maidens with whom Zeus fell in love in Greek mythology.

It is the largest satellite in the Solar System relative to the size of its planet, a quarter the diameter of Earth and 1/81 its mass; and is the second densest satellite after Io. It is in a synchronous relationship with the Earth, always showing the same face to Earth. The visible hemisphere is marked with dark volcanic lunar maria among the bright ancient mountains.

It was named after Europa, one of the many amorous conquests of Zeus in Greek mythology. Simon Marius suggested the name "Europe" after its discovery, but this name, and the name of the other Galilean moons were not commonly used until the mid-twentieth century. In much of the earlier astronomical literature it is mentioned for its Roman numeral designation, "Jupiter II" or as the "second satellite of Jupiter". It is the smallest of the Jovian or Galilean moons.

The sun is a star. It is a huge sphere of hot gas, constantly shining and turning. It seems much bigger and brighter than other stars because we are very close to it. The Sun is the center of our solar system. All the planets in our solar system, including Earth, revolve around the sun.

The Moon is the satellite of our planet, the Earth. It is called satellite because it revolves around us, and has done so more than four billion years. But where did it come from? Well, some astronomers think that it was once a part of our planet; and others think that it passed through our orbit and came so close to Earth that the force of the Earth\'s gravity attracted the moon, so that it stayed in our orbit forever.

A star is a huge, very hot and bright sphere of gas. Stars produce their own light and energy through a process called nuclear fusion. The merger happens when the lighter elements are forced to become heavier elements. When this happens, a tremendous amount of energy is created causing the star to heat up and shine. The stars are found in a extremely wide variety of sizes and colors. Our sun is a yellow star of average size. The stars that are smaller than our sun are red and the larger ones are blue.

A constellation is a group of stars that takes an imaginary shape in the night sky. They are usually named after mythological characters, people, animals and objects. In different parts of the world, people have invented different ways for the same groups of bright stars. This is like a game of connect the dots on a sheet of paper. In the past, creating imaginary images of the stars was useful for navigation at night and to follow the course of the seasons.

Spacecraft are vehicles designed to operate beyond the Earth\'s atmosphere, in outer space. There are 2 types of robotic ships; the ones that does not carry a crew and remain for a long time in space are more well known as satellites; and ships that carries astronauts as passengers. One of the best known is the Orion spacecraft, the Endeavour or Magellan, which were created by NASA and can accommodate up to 6 crew. It is important to know that a spacecraft is divided into several parts, has a kind of nerve system or brain that is what saves the information in its memory, and can communicate it in real time with the base on earth, and which can be commanded by astronauts.

Galaxies are huge collections of stars, dust and gas. Usually they contain from several millions to more than trillions stars and can vary in size from a few thousand to several hundred thousand light years across. There are hundreds of billions of galaxies in the universe. Galaxies come in many different sizes, shapes and brilliance, and like the stars, are found alone, in pairs or in larger groups called clusters. Galaxies are divided into three basic types: spiral, elliptical and irregular.
They form a drawing like a whirlpool with spiral arms; the center is mainly composed of old stars and the arms are mainly composed of young stars.
They are either circular or oval. This is the oldest type of galaxies found in the universe; they have very little interstellar gas and dust, and are composed mainly of old stars.

A lenticular galaxy is the type of galaxy between an elliptical galaxy and a spiral galaxy. Lenticular galaxies are disk-shaped (like spiral galaxies) that have consumed or lost much or all their interstellar matter (like elliptical galaxies), and therefore lack spiral arms, although sometimes there is a certain amount of interstellar matter, especially dust.
They are formless galaxies, either spiral, elliptical or lenticular. Some irregular galaxies are small spiral galaxies distorted by the gravity of a larger neighbor.
